Perhaps this is about the cards/table views and how they implement threading. You change that using the film strip looking icon beside the quickfilter button.

content: Filters search the body as it is displayed. So addservice.google.com will be found only if it is visible in the text of the email when you read it. The message source is not available to filters.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Here are the steps. This will bring a full copy of accounts and folders and settings to the new pc. The versions of thunderbird should be the same or nearly so. That is, if thunderbird on old PC is years behind on updates, I suggest updating there prior to copying to a pc with the latest release.

Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content:
Well, I respectfully disagree. You successfully coping the profile in your first attempt. Those extra profiles caused some confusion, but deleting wasn't necessary. Anyway, all is well. Here are steps to backup and possibly restore: here is the info in brief steps:

BACKUP

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

RESTORE

  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content:
Premessa: Thunderbird è un software gratuito offerto senza garanzie. E questo è solo un forum di utenti volontari. Se, come scrivi, quella casella di posta è vitale per l'azienda allora affidati ad un professionista poiché l'aiuto che puoi ricevere qui è inevitabilmente limitato e presuppone una attiva collaborazione.

Detto questo, senza conoscere i dettagli della configurazione non posso darti alcun suggerimento. Per cui dovresti fornire le seguenti informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
  9. Un link ai parametri di configurazione consigliati dal provider PEC

content:
It sounds like the same problem I'm having, and just joined to post.

They've changed/added something in the last update. In my case the popup window doesn't even fit on the screen. (I cannot see the top and bottom bars.) When it pops up it's not actually "active" or "selected" - so I have to stop what I'm doing, click on the white space, then hit the ESC key to get rid of the stupid thing for a while.

It wants me to login to a different Google account than the one I'm already logged into. All my family's different email accounts are loaded into one instance of Thunderbird, on the same computer - which has worked fine for years. I bet as soon as I do login to the other Google account like it wants, it will start demanding I log into the previous one.

Email still works fine on all accounts, so this pointless "log into Google account" window pop-up is change for the sake of change.

If the popup were at least "active" or "selected" when it appears, I could at least hit the ESC key while typing. But no - instead I have to remove my right hand from the keyboard, use the mouse to click on the white space - hit ESC - then turn the light on (I mostly work at night) to re-position my right hand on the keys (because the locating nub on my "J" key is worn flat). It's driving me nuts.

If they don't remove this "feature" in the next couple of updates, obviously that means they plan to keep it. So over the next few weeks I'll have to clean up all the email accounts, turn off the downloading of new email somehow, then email all the emails we want to keep to those same accounts so they become "new" email in the inbox (to make sure nothing is lost). Then I'll uninstall TB and find another email program, and download all the "new" email again.
creator: RealFamilyMan

Hate the thought of migrating to another mail client since I'm pretty happy with TB and am making monthly $$ contributions to the cause.

content:
Threading is "Per folder" and Thunderbird is not Outlook, so make no assumptions on how anything works based on the "Microsoft/Outlook way" or you will be about as disappointed as the users of Eudora where when it was discontinued and they filled forums with posts about how to make Thunderbird do things "the Eudora way". Thunderbird could not and many of the same points apply to Thunderbird and Outlook.

It is a good thing from my point of view that Thunderbird does not do things the Outlook way. I left the M$ fold when they invented their stupid ribbon toolbars. I like things to be where left them and I don't need a computer second guessing what needs to appear on a menu or toolbar, but in those days Thunderbird was also the only mail client that did threading of email.

In the knowledge that threading is per folder, I use the option to place a copy of replies in the folder I am replying from for just the reason you mention, so I have the original message and the reply in the same thread. Otherwise I have to right click and select open in conversation which is more frequent than I like as topics I initiate does not see the copy being in the folder the discussion ends up.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
purchase20 said
It didn't ask me what to set my password to. It said Primary Password Reset and it still asks for a password to reset it.

The code you have executed deleted all passwords stored in Thunderbird as well as removing the primary password, which is a password that is used to encrypt stored passwords whilst at rest is not going to set any passwords, it is simply going to remove from existence in Thunderbird any that did exist.

I do not see any request for a password in the image you posted. What I suspect is you are being prompted for your email account password that resetting your primary password will have deleted from Thunderbird.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: You are correct about the password prompt. But if I go to look at my saved passwords it asks me for my password which I assume was rest because it told me it did and it wiped out all of my saved passwords. So, I don't know or have a primary password to enter. That was why I reset it to begin with was to get a new primary password because I lost it. The attached screenshot is after I reset the passwords and I saved my email passwords again.
creator: purchase20

content:
Note: it says 'Windows Security' at the top of the small pop up window.

If you look at that pop up requesting password, it does not ask for your 'Primary Password' because you have removed it. Instead, you are seeing the 'Windows Security' request for password which operates by default.

When you start up computer, you get asked for a password to access your computer User Account to see desktop. It wants that password.
